Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Field and Laboratory Studies of Coastal Marine Processes at the Shannon Point Marine Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Division of Ocean Sciences provides renewed funding for a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at the Shannon Point Marine Center, Western Washington University (WWU), located in Bellingham, WA. The program will support 8 students for a nine-week internship over three years (2016-2018). Each student will work with an individual adviser to develop a research project that is independent and appropriately focused. The general theme focuses on living resources and processes of the local coastal marine environment, including primary and secondary productivity, biogeochemistry, microbial ecology and chemical ecology. With his/her adviser, each student develops and presents a project plan in a colloquium setting during the second week, conducts the research under the appropriate level of faculty supervision, and presents oral and written reports at the conclusion of the program. Publication of results and presentation at scientific meetings is strongly encouraged and supported.

The purpose of the SPMC REU is to introduce promising students to research at a point in their undergraduate programs that will permit informed decisions regarding pursuit of graduate education and scientific professions while preparing them to do so. Early in the program, students are introduced to the broad array of field and laboratory research techniques and are encouraged to use these in their own work. Group workshops are held on selecting and applying to graduate school, addressing issues of ethics in science, mastering data analysis and presentation methods, and effectively sharing science. Formal assessments provide both a feedback mechanism used to improve the program and an evaluation that documents outcomes and the longer-term value of the program. The program recruits applicants from around the United States, with special attention to underprivileged, underserved and underrepresented students, to those attending institutions with limited opportunities for undergraduate research, and to those whose current locations or previous experiences have not permitted ready access to marine environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the SPMC REU is to introduce promising students to research at a point in their undergraduate programs that permits informed decisions regarding pursuit of graduate education and scientific professions while preparing them to do so. We pursued this goal through a mentor-led research process and professional development activities that supplemented the research. Early in the program, students were introduced to the broad array of field and laboratory research techniques and were encouraged to use these in their own work. Students were then connected one-on-one with faculty mentors with assignments tailored to the needs and capabilities of each student. Group activities that promoted student-student interaction, near-peer mentoring, and access to the entire group of faculty mentors were developed along with workshops on applying to graduate school, ethics in science, data analysis and presentation, and sharing science. Each student worked with their individual adviser through the summer to develop and pursue a research project that was independent, relevant, and appropriately focused. The general research themes focuses on living resources and processes of the local coastal marine environment, including primary and secondary productivity, biogeochemistry, microbial ecology chemical ecology, and invertebrate life histories. At the end of the program, each student developed and presented an oral and written report summarizing their outcomes. 

Over the period of this grant, 24 students from 21 institutions completed the REU program. 41% of the participants' home institutions offered AAs or BSs as the terminal degree so those students previously had limited access to research opportunities. 54% of the REU participants were from groups underrepresented in the marine sciences. 37% were first generations students, 12% were non-traditional students, and 8% were veterans. The work the students completed resulted in, to date, 15 research presentations at science conferences. Some of those projects are moving toward publication in the refereed scienctific literature.
